repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
1. Added `on_range` callback to decoration provider that takes starting and ending rows and columns. 
2. Updated treesitter highlighter to use `on_range` instead of `on_line`. This improves performance for long lines, as query cursor doesn't have to be iterated for the entire line.
3. `iter_captures()` and its iterator now also accept columns.

closes #15405



The `on_range` callback might be called multiple times for the same line with different offsets. This is done because we can't predict how many characters will be visible (because of `conceal`, which can be added by the callback itself if I understand correctly, as well as multibyte and composing characters). 

Initial range is calculated from remaining number of cells and bytes in the line, assuming all characters are 1 byte and 1 cell wide. Then it is called every 100 bytes, and at EOL if it is visible.

The bounds are end-exclusivie and point to the first byte of the character. 

End point can be (number of lines, 0) since the range can include EOL of the last line.

### Results

| median, in ms | before | after|
|-|-|-|
| start of the line, with line wrapping | 19.75 | 0.97 |
| middle, `wrap` | 19.98 | 1.36 |
|middle, `wrap`, multibyte | 19.43 | 1.69 |
| end, `wrap` | 20.96 | 1.79 |
| start, `nowrap` | 19.78 | 0.19 |
| middle, `nowrap` | 20.25 | 0.65 |
| end, `nowrap` | 20.07 | 1.04 |
| bigger screen, `wrap` (visible ~36% of the line) | 88.6 | 30.2 |

### What needs to be done:

- [x] Some tests are failing. See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31400#issuecomment-2509509887 for details.
- [x] The API needs to be updated properly, without `tslua_push_querycursor2()` and `iter_captures2()`.
- [x] Benchmarks, tests, news.
- [x] Find a better heuristic for the callback range.

comment_data.body: Why was `ts_query_cursor_exec()` called before the range, depth and limit were set?

Why did the previous implementation include the `erow` line?

`self:prepare_highlight_states` above expects end line to be exclusive.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -375,9 +411,7 @@ function TSHighlighter._on_spell_nav(_, _, buf, srow, _, erow, _)
   local highlight_states = self._highlight_states
   self:prepare_highlight_states(srow, erow)
 
-  for row = srow, erow do
-    on_line_impl(self, buf, row, true)
-  end
+  on_range_impl(self, buf, srow, 0, erow, 0, true)

comment_data.body: The depth and limit aren't used until you start iterating.

```suggestion
      • {opts}    (`{ start_col?: integer, stop_col?: integer }?`) Optional
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1425,9 +1425,11 @@ Query:iter_captures({node}, {source}, {start}, {stop})
                   `node:start()`.
       • {stop}    (`integer?`) Stopping line for the search (end-exclusive).
                   Defaults to `node:end_()`.
+      • {opts}    (`{ col_begin?: integer, col_end?: integer }?`) Optional

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
Query:iter_captures({node}, {source}, {start_row}, {stop_row}, {opts})
```

May be worth changing `stop` -> `end` since that's what we use everywhere else.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1386,7 +1386,7 @@ parse({lang}, {query})                          *vim.treesitter.query.parse()*
       • |vim.treesitter.query.get()|
 
                                                        *Query:iter_captures()*
-Query:iter_captures({node}, {source}, {start}, {stop})
+Query:iter_captures({node}, {source}, {start}, {stop}, {opts})

comment_data.body:
Again, prefer the terms `start/end` for ranges. So this would be
```suggestion
  start_row,
  start_col,
  end_row,
  end_col,
```

```suggestion
      start_row = start,

      end_row = stop_row,

```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -959,28 +960,37 @@ end
 ---@param source (integer|string) Source buffer or string to extract text from
 ---@param start? integer Starting line for the search. Defaults to `node:start()`.
 ---@param stop? integer Stopping line for the search (end-exclusive). Defaults to `node:end_()`.
+---@param opts? { col_begin?: integer, col_end?: integer } Optional parameters.
 ---
----@return (fun(end_line: integer|nil): integer, TSNode, vim.treesitter.query.TSMetadata, TSQueryMatch, TSTree):
+---@return (fun(end_line: integer|nil, end_col: integer|nil): integer, TSNode, vim.treesitter.query.TSMetadata, TSQueryMatch, TSTree):
 ---        capture id, capture node, metadata, match, tree
 ---
 ---@note Captures are only returned if the query pattern of a specific capture contained predicates.
-function Query:iter_captures(node, source, start, stop)
+function Query:iter_captures(node, source, start, stop, opts)
   if type(source) == 'number' and source == 0 then
     source = api.nvim_get_current_buf()
   end
 
+  opts = opts or {}
   start, stop = value_or_node_range(start, stop, node)
 
+  local cursor_opts = {
+    row_begin = start,
+    col_begin = opts.col_begin,
+    row_end = stop,
+    col_end = opts.col_end,
+    match_limit = 256,
+  }
   -- Copy the tree to ensure it is valid during the entire lifetime of the iterator
   local tree = node:tree():copy()
-  local cursor = vim._create_ts_querycursor(node, self.query, start, stop, { match_limit = 256 })
+  local cursor = vim._create_ts_querycursor(node, self.query, cursor_opts)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
          local outside = end_line ~= nil and (end_col and cmp_ge(row, col, end_line, end_col) or row > end_line)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1005,10 +1015,19 @@ function Query:iter_captures(node, source, start, stop)
         local predicates = processed_pattern.predicates
         if not self:_match_predicates(predicates, pattern_i, captures, source) then
           cursor:remove_match(match_id)
-          if end_line and captured_node:range() > end_line then
+          local row, col = captured_node:range()
+          local outside = false
+          if end_line then
+            if end_col then
+              outside = cmp_ge(row, col, end_line, end_col)
+            else
+              outside = row > end_line
+            end
+          end

comment_data.body: What is this block for?
Is this function strictly necessary? Wouldn't it be better to just validate the inputs are u32?
Wraparound when value is converted to `uint32_t`. If it is 2^32 + some value, 2^32 will be discarded

I prefer to clamp the values rather than to fail. My lgic it that people convert between end-inclusive and end-exclusive, or 0/1-based by adding/subtracting 1. If the value they are converting is 0 or maxcol, then not clamping will produce errors in that one case.

Call `on_range()` again if the approximation was too small, and we need more highlighting information for the current line.
This can happen if there were multibyte characters or `conceal`.
Is `start`/`end` preferred over `begin`/`end`?

This conflicts with the node range:
```lua
      local start_row, start_col, end_row, end_col = Range.unpack4(range)
```

comment_data.body:
```lua
(end_col and cmp_ge(row, col, end_line, end_col) or row > end_line)
```
 
If `end_col` exists, but `cmp_ge(row, col, end_line, end_col)` is `false`, then `row > end_line` will also be evaluated.
It won't give a different result, but for me, this is more confusing than the `if` version.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1005,10 +1015,19 @@ function Query:iter_captures(node, source, start, stop)
         local predicates = processed_pattern.predicates
         if not self:_match_predicates(predicates, pattern_i, captures, source) then
           cursor:remove_match(match_id)
-          if end_line and captured_node:range() > end_line then
+          local row, col = captured_node:range()
+          local outside = false
+          if end_line then
+            if end_col then
+              outside = cmp_ge(row, col, end_line, end_col)
+            else
+              outside = row > end_line
+            end
+          end

comment_data.body: could we extract this block out of `win_line` ?

`end_col and cmp_ge(row, col, end_line, end_col) or row > end_line` would mean that when `end_col` exists but `cmp_ge(...)` is false, it would check `row > end_line`, which doesn't change the result but I think is misleading. 

Should I change it?

comment_data.body: related to discussion of deprecation, we could make setting both `on_range` and `on_line` for the same provider an error already, to make it clear that the former is a replacement for the latter.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1063,6 +1071,7 @@ void nvim_set_decoration_provider(Integer ns_id, Dict(set_decoration_provider) *
     { "on_buf", &opts->on_buf, &p->redraw_buf },
     { "on_win", &opts->on_win, &p->redraw_win },
     { "on_line", &opts->on_line, &p->redraw_line },
+    { "on_range", &opts->on_range, &p->redraw_range },

comment_data.body: source bytes are not that expensive, we can call it `start_row` and so on:)

Conversion shouldn't change valid values to invalid tho, then they were already invalid in the source representation. IMO this is too generic and a bad code pattern and hides a lot of decisions which should be spelled out at the specific sites. 

better to spell out MIN or MAX in individual cases based on what makes sense (which can be semantic, not based on accidents of C integer types). When -1 is allowed it also typically means something different than a passive alias of 0, like a synonym for "unlimited". If there is no use of -1 yet it is better to leave it as an error so that it safely can be allowed later with a useful use.

It's a bit unfortunate if this needs to be this much more complex. If the range becomes empty (as a result of the fold clipping) can't we skip the `for_each` completely? 

Also when a particular tree root is empty, we can just skip the tree at that point, right?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -328,45 +335,89 @@ end
 ---Queues the remainder if the mark continues after the line.
 ---@param m MarkInfo
 ---@param buf integer
----@param line integer
+---@param range_start_row integer
+---@param range_start_col integer
+---@param range_end_row integer
+---@param range_end_col integer
 ---@param next_marks MarkInfo[]
-local function add_mark(m, buf, line, next_marks)
+local function add_mark(
+  m,
+  buf,
+  range_start_row,
+  range_start_col,
+  range_end_row,
+  range_end_col,
+  next_marks
+)
   local cur_start_l = m.start_line
   local cur_start_c = m.start_col
-  if cur_start_l < line then
-    cur_start_l = line
-    cur_start_c = 0
+  if cmp_lt(cur_start_l, cur_start_c, range_start_row, range_start_col) then
+    cur_start_l = range_start_row
+    cur_start_c = range_start_col
   end
 
   local cur_opts = m.opts
-  if cur_opts.end_line >= line + 1 then
+  if cmp_lt(range_end_row, range_end_col, cur_opts.end_line, cur_opts.end_col) then
     cur_opts = vim.deepcopy(cur_opts, true)
-    cur_opts.end_line = line + 1
-    cur_opts.end_col = 0
+    cur_opts.end_line = range_end_row
+    cur_opts.end_col = range_end_col
     table.insert(next_marks, m)
   end
 
-  local empty = cur_opts.end_line < cur_start_l
-    or (cur_opts.end_line == cur_start_l and cur_opts.end_col <= cur_start_c)
-  if cur_start_l <= line and not empty then
+  if cmp_lt(cur_start_l, cur_start_c, cur_opts.end_line, cur_opts.end_col) then
     api.nvim_buf_set_extmark(buf, ns, cur_start_l, cur_start_c, cur_opts)
   end
 end
 
 ---@param self vim.treesitter.highlighter
 ---@param win integer
 ---@param buf integer
----@param line integer
+---@param range_start_row integer
+---@param range_start_col integer
+---@param range_end_row integer
+---@param range_end_col integer
 ---@param on_spell boolean
 ---@param on_conceal boolean
-local function on_line_impl(self, win, buf, line, on_spell, on_conceal)
-  self._conceal_checked[line] = self._conceal_line and true or nil
+local function on_range_impl(
+  self,
+  win,
+  buf,
+  range_start_row,
+  range_start_col,
+  range_end_row,
+  range_end_col,
+  on_spell,
+  on_conceal
+)
+  if self._conceal_line then
+    range_start_col = 0
+    if range_end_col ~= 0 then
+      range_end_row = range_end_row + 1
+      range_end_col = 0
+    end
+  end
+  for i = range_start_row, range_end_row - 1 do
+    self._conceal_checked[i] = self._conceal_line or nil
+  end
   self:for_each_highlight_state(win, function(state)
     local root_node = state.tstree:root()
-    local root_start_row, _, root_end_row, _ = root_node:range()
+    local root_start_row, root_start_col, root_end_row, root_end_col = root_node:range()
+
+    --- @type boolean
+    local root_intersects
+
+    local range_empty = cmp_eq(range_start_row, range_start_col, range_end_row, range_end_col)
+    local root_empty = cmp_eq(root_start_row, root_start_col, root_end_row, root_end_col)
+    if not range_empty and not root_empty then
+      root_intersects = cmp_lt(range_start_row, range_start_col, root_end_row, root_end_col)
+        and cmp_lt(root_start_row, root_start_col, range_end_row, range_end_col)
+    else
+      root_intersects = cmp_lte(range_start_row, range_start_col, root_end_row, root_end_col)
+        and cmp_lte(root_start_row, root_start_col, range_end_row, range_end_col)
+    end

comment_data.body:
If someone makes the root node of the tree line conceal lines, and the tree is an empty injection, then we need this comparison.

Though it wouldn't work either way, since `Range.intersection()` considers empty ranges to not be intersecting.

I'll remove this check.

comment_data.body: I reverted it to how it was working originally
`test/functional/ui/decorations_spec.lua` adds both callbacks
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1063,6 +1071,7 @@ void nvim_set_decoration_provider(Integer ns_id, Dict(set_decoration_provider) *
     { "on_buf", &opts->on_buf, &p->redraw_buf },
     { "on_win", &opts->on_win, &p->redraw_win },
     { "on_line", &opts->on_line, &p->redraw_line },
+    { "on_range", &opts->on_range, &p->redraw_range },

comment_data.body: This would silently ignore `col_begin` if `row_begin` is not set. Let's just make things simple by allowing either separately. Then we don't even need any if statements as the default values are specified above. Some for `col_end`
We can address the deprecation in a follow-up:)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1063,6 +1071,7 @@ void nvim_set_decoration_provider(Integer ns_id, Dict(set_decoration_provider) *
     { "on_buf", &opts->on_buf, &p->redraw_buf },
     { "on_win", &opts->on_win, &p->redraw_win },
     { "on_line", &opts->on_line, &p->redraw_line },
+    { "on_range", &opts->on_range, &p->redraw_range },

comment_regular_data.body: Cool! Idk if you had seen the conceal_lines PR at all but it currently contains a commit that would affect this (or the other way around), and seemingly force the `on_range` callback here to still iterate over a table of all marks in a line. [`03f132a` (#31324)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31324/commits/03f132a3e81942ce848dad3655c2b125ce966e16). Although perhaps `on_range` could remove handled entries from the prepared highlight state to avoid that.

One of the reasons the tests are failing is because highlights are sometimes added when they are outside the current range ([see comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30869#issuecomment-2430570060)). 

For example, `supports language injections` test fails because the injection tree iterator is created at the end of the first line, and adds its first match (on the second line) before highlights from the main tree.  Before, the iterator for the injection would be created on the second line, after highlights from the main tree for that line were added. There are probably more issues similar to this.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/2833925cfc688786759d6a980a1ad62b62d20570/test/functional/treesitter/highlight_spec.lua#L860-L863

UPD:
Fixed the failing functional test.

This doesn't mean the bug described in the [comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30869#issuecomment-2430570060) is fixed.

Now initial range is calculated from the number of cells remaining to be drawn.

Is using `w_width_inner` correct, or should it be `w_width`? Are they different in multigrid?
For `nowrap`, if EOL is not visible, the transition range (from one line to the other) is not called. This means the iterator will be recreated.
`w_width_inner` should be used for the rendering of text in a window

I should also mention that there's another possible issue:

Injection highlights might get obscured by main highlights if both overlap have the same priority. This can happen if main highlight is positioned after injection highlight, and they are added in separate ranges. Because insertion order takes priority over position, "older" injection highlight would be hidden by "newer" main highlight. If they were added in the same range, the order would be reversed.

This is not a new issue, since the same applies to lines. If injection highlight spans multiple lines, and main highlight gets added e.g. on the second line.

I wasn't able to come up with any examples of this behavior, though.
Added benchmarks.

### Before

`Before` becomes faster at the end of the line because there are less decorations to iterate (since the ones before the cursor are removed).

There's not much difference because the screen size is small.

Updated the API.

`iter_captures()` now has an optional `opts` table with begin and end columns, and the iterator also accepts `end_col`.
`iter_captures()` remains backwards-compatible, but that means default values (from node bounds) are only used for lines and not for columns.

~~Docs and news for on_range() are not yet written since I'm not sure what the contract should be. Currently, the characters are considered included if their first byte in inside the range, and begin/end positions can be on any byte. This means that if begin position is in the middle of a character, it is not included; and if end position is in the middle of a character, it IS included.~~

~~This seems convoluted, but that's the easiest way, and treesitter query cursor also interprets the bounds this way AFAIK.~~

~~There's also a theoretical problem with this approach if a treesitter node can start in the middle of a sequence of composing characters.~~

~~Should I make it so that range bounds always point to a first byte?~~

Bounds now always point to the first byte. Added docs and news.

Rebased.

For line concealing, optimization is disabled and lines are checked fully.
rebased

This PR is planned for consideration as part of the 0.12 release. There's no exact timeline yet. See https://matrix.to/#/!HCjHPBLFfoFpYNgwdE:matrix.org/$6xErSQAp5sdi5rMev7uU7yCG-NaUM9pmcvKzy7gCFMQ?via=matrix.org&via=phorcys.net&via=graven.dev

This looks great, let's get it merged.

> 2\. Updated treesitter highlighter to use `on_range` instead of `on_line`. This improves performance for long lines, as query cursor doesn't have to be iterated for the entire line.
> ...
> The `on_range` callback might be called multiple times for the same line

Could we deprecate `on_line` or does it have a strong purpose still?

> Could we deprecate on_line or does it have a strong purpose still?

~Tbh I don't think it does~.  One thing is that `on_range` can be called multiple times for one line which I don't think is desirable for a few downstream users I'm aware of, if not all. Most `on_line` users will likely need to fetch the whole line if they apply decorations based on buffer text.

Would be good to get a review from either @luukvbaal , @zeertzjq or @bfredl

Yeah `on_lines` definitely should go away soon enough (at least in 0.13)

>  One thing is that on_range can be called multiple times for one line which I don't think is desirable for a few downstream users I'm aware of, if not all. Most on_line users will likely need to fetch the whole line if they apply decorations based on buffer text.

I think this is fine as long as reasonably short (say < 120 vcols) lines are always not split up. once lines grow longer, I think it is good that the interface strongly hints that plugins should try to support partial lines more effectively.  Core does not handle super long lines well either _right now_, but we are planning for a future when we might and it is good that the interface reflects that..

> I think it is good that the interface strongly hints that plugins should try to support partial lines more effectively.

There are also applications which are agnostic to line contents. E.g. Gitsigns which just wants to know when the gutter for a line is on screen, this most likely extends to all sign provider plugins. These plugins would need some heuristic/mechanism they can rely on to safely be able to skip repeated range callbacks for the same line.

Another instance I'm thinking of is a colorizer plugin that would need to consume the whole line to perform a match on, as only performing a match on a chunk can yield false negative results if the color code crosses the chunk boundary. EDIT: I guess such plugins can just add some error margin when getting the line to guaratee no false-negative results.

yeah, I think a "range" callback should always be able to defer the next call from the same provider to an explicit later position if it knows there is no more data to produce (regardless if this is a later column position or a later line, which as a special case can be the beginning of the next buffer line if there potentially is a sign there).
it is getting late here but taking a good look at the details will be a prio for my upcoming work week:)
Mostly rebased. I'll fix the remaining errors and add reviewed changes tomorrow
